member.name: T:Dapper.Database.Adapters.Oracle11gAdapter
member.summary: Oracle database adapter for Oracle 11g.

member.name: M:Dapper.Database.Adapters.Oracle11gAdapter.BuildInsertQuery(Dapper.Database.TableInfo)
member.summary: Simulates INSERT..RETURNING with a PL/SQL block that does an INSERT followed by a SELECT.
member.returns: the PL/SQL block

remarks.para: ORACRAP: The managed ODP.Net drivers do not properly handle variable-sized outputs when running an UPDATE..RETURNING against Oracle 11g. I suspect this is the result of a difference in what is sent over the wire between 11.2 and 12.2, and the managed driver not handling the difference.

This holds true even if we run UPDATE..RETURNING in a PL/SQL block. However, it *does* properly work on INSERT..RETURNING and a PL/SQL block doing UPDATE, then SELECT. There should be no risk of a race condition as the row should be locked for the duration of the execution.

member.name: M:Dapper.Database.Adapters.Oracle11gAdapter.BuildUpdateQuery(Dapper.Database.TableInfo,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Simulates UPDATE..RETURNING with a PL/SQL block that does an UPDATE followed by a SELECT.
member.returns: the PL/SQL block

remarks.para: ORACRAP: The managed ODP.Net drivers do not properly handle variable-sized outputs when running an UPDATE..RETURNING against Oracle 11g. I suspect this is the result of a difference in what is sent over the wire between 11.2 and 12.2, and the managed driver not handling the difference.

This holds true even if we run UPDATE..RETURNING in a PL/SQL block. However, it *does* properly work on INSERT..RETURNING and a PL/SQL block doing UPDATE, then SELECT. There should be no risk of a race condition as the row should be locked for the duration of the execution.

member.name: M:Dapper.Database.Adapters.OracleAdapter.ResolveRowCount(System.Int32,Dapper.DynamicParameters)
member.summary: Resolves row count depending on whether the statement return count is from PL/SQL or not.
member.param: The statement return count (can be -1, 0, or a positive number).
The parameters used in the statement.
member.returns: The actual count (zero or more).
member.remarks: PL/SQL blocks will automatically return -1 for rows affected. The only way to get an accurate count is to bind an additional variable in PL/SQL and capture the builtin variable ROW_COUNT$$; this is the name of the bind variable containing the value.
